video.title: Build a Chrome Extension – Course for Beginners
video.description:
Learn how to create a Chrome browser extension using JavaScript and the new iteration of the web extensions platform, called Manifest V3.

✏️ Raman Hundal developed this tutorial.

💻 YouTube Bookmarker Starter Code: https://github.com/raman-at-pieces/youtube-bookmarker-starter-code
💻 YouTube Bookmarker Finished Code: https://github.com/raman-at-pieces/youtube-bookmarker-finished-code
🔗 Pieces Code Snippet Assistant download: https://pieces.app/install

🔗 Publishing extension on the chrome store docs: https://developer.chrome.com/docs/webstore/publish/

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Intro
⌨️ (0:02:15) Demo
⌨️ (0:05:18) Understanding manifest.json
⌨️ (0:08:46) Coding the extention
⌨️ (0:31:37) newVideoLoaded function
⌨️ (0:31:37) fetchBookmarks
⌨️ (0:37:08) addEventListener
⌨️ (0:48:03) addNewBookmark function
⌨️ (1:00:33) Testing the extention

🎉 Thanks to Pieces.app for providing a grant that made this course possible.

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Raymond Odero
👾 Agustín Kussrow
👾 aldo ferretti
👾 Otis Morgan
👾 DeezMaster

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: ShadeTree HandyMan
topLevelComment.text:
How hard would it be to make a randomizer for youtube?
As a long time youtube viewer and maker of a few videos the user interface for youtube has become mind numbingly boring and repetitive. It used to be somewhat of an adventure when you went to your youtube home page and be presented with a wide and somewhat unpredictable choice of videos. Sadly this is no long true... you are constantly shown videos that either the same video you just watched or similar ones.... or worse shown the same videos day in and day out for weeks if you dont reject them.  I often go through and check the dont recommend channel on a whole page of videos hit the reload button and hope for better choices. 

So would it be possible to make a chrome extension that could automate this process in some way such as take the fist 10 or however many videos presented and  do the dont recommend channel for each and then reload the page. I will add that I tend to do all my youtubing on a computer and not on a phone.

topLevelComment.author: Timur Timaev
topLevelComment.text:
I was struggling at first few minutes. I was not getting tab.url. Then googled up onUpdated and got this:

in background.js you also have to add another param like this
chrome.tabs.onUpdated.addListener((tabId, changeInfo, tab) ...

then it works. gonna continue now...

topLevelComment.author: Sheroz Nazhmudinov
topLevelComment.text:
Nice tutorial, thanks! I have noticed smth - the extension isn't alway loaded when navigating from, let's say www.youtube.com, to some specific video.
Only after the reload, the extension is loaded and the + sign is visible.

I put some log statements in the background.js and contentScript.js (around the message sending and handling parts), and I can see the message doesn't always get consumer in the contentScript.js, even though it's sent by the background.js. 

Do you know if it's some sort of bug in the extension framework, or do we need to listen to a different event?

topLevelComment.author: the cats Krümel and Keksi
topLevelComment.text: Just for understanding: Where are the bookmarks stored?

replies.author: MonkMode
replies.text:
It's been 2 months since you asked this, but I still wanted to answer this:

These bookmarks stored at the local storage of chrome. Many browser extensions store their data in the browser's so-called Local Storage, which is nothing else than a storage location managed by the web browser. And as the same suggests, all is saved locally on the machine where the browser is installed.

topLevelComment.author: Paul The Pigeon
topLevelComment.text:
for anyone thinking of making one and putting it in their resume: i would not recommend this for a resume project. 

1. it’s hard to get a ton of people to use
2. the person reading your resume / recruiter will not open their computer and look for your extension to download. too much barriers so stick to normal projects.

replies.author: frodelius
replies.text: @Paul The Pigeon It doesn't work either so... Can you help in making it work? That would be something to put on your resume!

replies.author: Paul The Pigeon
replies.text:
@TJ Hooper i would still not recommend a chrome extension as a project to put on your resume and i know other experienced developers who say the same. There are many other projects that aren't chrome extensions that get people SWE jobs.

Your extension would have to big massively successful, used by thousands or hundreds of thousands of people for it to hold any weight on your resume. recruiters see tons of resume's daily and they will not stop to search for, download and try out your chrome extension.

replies.author: TJ Hooper
replies.text: This may be true, but also how many people put chrome extension projects on their resume? Especially junior developers? This could help a candidate stand out and show he/she is willing to learn more than the rudimentary todo list project.
